awd_titl_txt: Early Career: Technician Support for an organic and stable isotope biogeochemistry laboratory focused on climate and water-related natural hazards
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will fund a full-time technician for three years in the Biogeochemistry Laboratory at the University at Buffalo. The principal investigator is an early-career geoscientist who will conduct research focused on understanding mechanisms of changes in water availability related to climate variability. The laboratory reconstructs past climate by examining sediments that record minute geochemical signatures of past environmental conditions. The studies will be conducted on samples from all around the world, including temperate regions, where large populations and food production occur, and the Arctic system, where sea ice loss will affect precipitation and in turn affect ice sheets and sea level rise. The research results have important societal implications for planning for droughts, floods, extreme storm events, and ice sheet mass loss.  The project will enhance the principal investigator's partnership with the Buffalo Audubon Society for education and outreach, which includes a citizen-scientist program activity for the collection of weekly sediment and precipitation samples.

The funding of a full-time technician at the University at Buffalo for three years will immediately increase the research productivity of an early-career geoscientist and establish the basis for long-term support for the position. The technician will be employed in the principal investigator's Organic and Stable Isotope Biogeochemistry Laboratory, which contains state-of-the-art equipment for sample extraction, preparation, and analysis at high spatial and temporal resolution. The laboratory's research goal is to provide prehistorical context for and mechanistic understanding of water-related changes associated with climate change. Potentially harmful consequences, such as droughts, floods, extreme storm events, and ice sheet mass loss, are of high societal and environmental significance, as they affect ecosystem stability, hydroelectric and agricultural production, and ice sheets and sea level rise. The increased research capacity of the laboratory enables more activities in the education and outreach partnership with the Buffalo Audubon Society, which includes teaching diverse groups about the glacial and climate history of New York, involving school-age summer camp groups in sample collection, participating in career days that expose young adults to a broad range of environmental careers, and analyzing samples from a citizen-science program.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to hire, train, and employ for three years a full-time technician for the University at Buffalo Organic and Stable Isotope Biogeochemistry Lab of early-career researcher Dr. Elizabeth Thomas. Mr. Owen Cowling, the Organic and Stable Isotope Biogeochemistry Lab manager hired by this grant, has become an integral part of Dr. Thomas' research group and of the UB Geology Department. He started full time in June 2018, following a yearlong graduate assistantship as lab technician. Mr. Cowling helped to set up new instruments purchased during lab start-up, coordinated and oversaw electrical and intranet renovations with UB Facilities, and established written protocols for sample preparation, instrument use, and data processing. He trained students and visiting researchers from within and outside the University at Buffalo (UB) in lab safety, analytical techniques, and data processing. Mr. Cowling conducted inventory, ordered supplies and consumables, conducted instrument maintenance and repairs, and interfaced with UB Facilities and IT departments for all building- and computer-related issues.

Mr. Cowling developed a cost structure for the lab and advertised the lab services to any user in the world via a lab website that he developed and via the UB Shared Facilities website. He made invoices and received payments for all analyses conducted in the lab. Moving forward, these analytical services will support researchers who do not have access to stable isotope and organic geochemistry facilities at their institutions.

In addition, when New York State closed all SUNY campuses in March 2020 due to the pandemic, Mr. Cowling ensured that all samples and reagents were stored safely and instruments were properly shut down. He also reopened the lab in June 2020: he drafted our Lab Operations Plan (required by the University at Buffalo's reopening plan), got instruments back up and running, handled additional paperwork associated with granting lab users access to the lab, and trained all lab researchers in the new safety protocols.

Having a full-time manager to oversee the analytical facilities and student training allowed Dr. Thomas to focus on writing grant proposals and publications and on mentoring and supporting students, which has been especially challenging since the pandemic began in March 2020. During the span of this grant, Dr. Thomas mentored 16 undergraduate, 8 MS and 5 PhD students, all of whom conducted research in the lab under Mr. Cowling's mentorship, and ⅓ of whom are ethnic, racial, or gender minorities (not counting women) that are underrepresented in the Earth Sciences. All students who have graduated from Dr. Thomas' group have gone on to graduate school and/or careers in the Earth Sciences. Dr. Thomas' team produced 16 peer-reviewed journal articles, 63 abstracts at conferences, 1 doctoral dissertation, and 2 MS theses during the lifetime of this grant. Dr. Thomas and her team used the lab facility to enrich UB courses and outreach efforts, including Earth Ed Institute, a continuing education course for high school science teachers, jointly led by the UB Geology and Environment and Sustainability departments.
